commentBody: I confess to having tried pARA Sea before finally entering the K.

Geoffrey, you could have created a special surname for yourself, to fit the theme of this fun puzzle:
SCHORKPF

The groom said "A, E, I, O, U, and sometimes Y." They were some of the most beautiful wedding vowels I ever heard.

("Haha. Marry funny.")
And sometimes PMTRYSTS.

I was a initially disappointed  by the pretty obvious vowels in the circle and what I thought was too straightforward clueing for the LGBTQFLAG clue (even for a Tuesday); but gotta say became more impressed once I caught on to the fact that all those long answers had only one vowel; that was pretty spiffy, I must admit. Clever idea and well executed. Great collaboration!

I saw the vowel progression, and popped in the O and the U before getting to those entries, and with only the B in place I guessed BUY A VOWEL would be the revealer, but it didn't really register with me until after finishing that the five theme entries had only one vowel. The OREOS are forgiven. 
Nice one, Geoffrey and Will.

Tuesday puzzles don‚Äôt get much better than this! The theme isn‚Äôt too gimmicky, and everything feels fresh and interesting. Beautiful fill. Kudos to Geoffrey and Will. Best Tuesday I‚Äôve played in a long time.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend Review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/12/29/tuesday-december-30-2025/#ny
This was a lot of fun and well done. I thoroughly enjoyed it!
But OREOS was in this!

Very impressive. It‚Äôs tough to come up with 8 or 9 letters phrases that contain just one vowel. And the revealer comes so close to containing one of each vowel. Too bad it couldn‚Äôt have been the phrase often uttered by contestants, (I'LL) BUY A VOWEL. 

Congratulations, Geoffrey and Will. You created a puzzle with many strengths*. 

*the longest word containing just one vowel
I'm not a native English speaker and I am so confused with 37 down. I tried to google it but I didn't find anything. Can you tell me what it means please?
No EPEE today, but our old friend ORCA made an appearance. Which one was used first? And which one more often? ü§î
Laid up with a cold so knocked out October ‚Äò13 in the archive. Just November and December of ‚Äò13 to go to complete the archive.

My old eyes are too dim to see the circles. Have I mentioned ever how much I dislike them and could they be made more visible? :-)

Anyhoo, I read Sam‚Äôs blog entry and I am blown away by how they played out! Well done, my fellow ‚ÄúGeoff with a G‚Äù!

Tuesday morning I'll be in the hospital for a procedure, so I'm grateful to have this cleanly crafted puzzle to calm my jitters.  

Thank you Geoffrey and Will.  Good job.

I‚Äôm a fan of Wheel of Fortune, so I appreciated this nod to the game. Tight theme well done. Perfect Tuesday. My brother rode a BMX when we were kids and learned to do a front somersault on his by sticking his shoe into the spokes of the front tire as he rode down a shallow hill from our school on the way home. üò± I don‚Äôt know how he avoided injury?! If I ever tried this, I‚Äôm certain I would have WENT PFFT ü§£ Broken bones at a minimum!
My youngest was born in TX and the nurses at the hospital tried to convince me that I needed to order the special TX birth certificate in case they ever SECEDEd from the US. It‚Äôs the ‚Äúheirloom‚Äù birth certificate üôÑ
Given how many crossword puzzles rely on the familiar 'crosswordese' answers to wedge vowels in where needed, it's refreshing to see a puzzle built around a constraint. Breezy and fun!
Pulling out the lesser known definition of PERUSE again! (For those who were unaware and missed it a few weeks ago, PERUSE is a contronym.)
Had the hardest time trying to remember what that bike with three letters is called‚Ä¶ All I could think of was BMW, which I knew was wrong. Sigh‚Ä¶
Wow, nice 5 letter acronym! I had the entire right side solved first, thanks to the cool theme!
Clever, fresh, and fun
I finished the last two Tuesday puzzles in exactly 11:17. Fun coincidence.

As a Pole I can confirm we are indeed extremes of the Earth.

That was a neat trick. Finding several entries with just one vowel? Even ever curmudgeonly me was impressed by this feat.

I learned of AEIOU from these puzzles btw. I was stumped the first time I encountered it as a crossword entry - or was it a theme? Btw, in Polish Y is always a vowel - we generally pronounce every letter only one way, so they never suffer from audio-schizophrenia üòâ. I had never thought about it before so I was surprised (in the discussion of that past puzzle) to learn that in English Y may be either a consonant or a vowel.

The puzzle felt quite hard for me on the across pass - I had to rely mostly on the downs to solve it - yet I finished in Monday rather than Tuesday time. Go figure. I found yesterday's grid more challenging than today's.

Wheel of Fortune (Ko≈Ço Fortuny) was among the first "Western" gameshows licensed by a Polish broadcaster under our new democracy. We all watched it in the early 90s. The lady who turned the letters on the board - Magda Masny - became one of Poland's first post-1989 celebrities.
Thanks Geoffrey and Will. Such fun.
Would a kind person out there explain 1 Down to me, please?

Very nice Tuesday puzzle.  Not only did Geoffrey and Will find 5 entries with only one vowel each, but all 5 were debuts.  The revealer was also a debut. Add to that, they managed to put the 5 vowels in order.

AUSPICIOUS is also a debut, and that seems appropriate for this DUO's future in construction.

I'm sure this is an oversight and not maliciously greedy (although you never know these days), but I shared the link to the "how to solve the NYT crossword" article to a friend who has a games subscription (like me), and its paywalled behind a full subscription.

Can the NYT confirm this is the intent and if not could it be fixed?  Like I say probably an oversight but would not be surprised if this was deliberate

It‚Äôs not a STRETCH to say that the constructors went to great LENGTHS, the puzzle had many STRENGTHS, with nary a SPLOTCH.  They earned their SCRATCH and should celebrate, perhaps with SCHNAPPS, no STRINGS attached.

This is a tight theme.  It‚Äôs hard enough to come up with phrases of eight letters or more that contain but one vowel.  Then to find A-E-I-O-U answers, and to find letter counts to fit symmetry (four nines and two eights today) ‚Äì well, high props on that!

And then to sprinkle beauty throughout the grid, with PERUSED, GLITTER, SQUALL, AUSPICIOUS on top of that ‚Äì wow!

The reveal is clever; the whole idea is clever.  This puzzle is so well made and well-conceived.  

Serendipity watch.  Lovely theme echoes of longer words with just one vowel (NESTS, JOLTS, EMPTY).  And then there's the vowel-only answer (OUIOUI) to bring balance to the vowel-shy theme.

And I loved the PuzzPair¬© of EMPTY/NESTS.

Geoffrey and Will, what a shiny jewel you made.  Thank you for brightening my day!
And SO TO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CZSw6gFEUW8&list=RDCZSw6gFEUW8&start_radio=1
I loved this theme!

Really nice puzzle. For whatever reason, I found it easier than yesterday's puzzle but it made for a flowy solve which I appreciated. 

It's tight, it's simple, the clues don't stretch too much to make the theme work, and there were just enough tricky ones to keep a bit of tension. Well done.

Nice Tuesday workout and a really enjoyable theme. Great moment to finally work out the reveal and then go back and review and catch on to the trick. Can't help but wonder about long words or terms with a minimum number of vowels. Best I could come up with so far is: FLIGHTLESSBIRD. Feel free to chip in. 

Oh, and puzzle find today. A Monday from May 8, 2017 by Zhouqin Burnikel, Theme answers: 

ELLEFANNING
GEEYATHINK
BEEBALM
TEAKETTLES
CUETHEMUSIC

And then the 'reveal' with a clue that referenced all five of those answers: 

LGBTQ

I'm done. 

...

"___ Sea (arm of the Arctic Ocean)" seems an awfully tough clue to use on a Tuesday. YIKES/KARA might well have been YIPES/PARA, though KARA seems a bit more Arctic-sounding to me than PARA does. To me, this crossing was a true "natick", which could have been avoided simply by cluing KARA as a female name. I actually had to guess here, which seems like a rare event for a Tuesday. Perhaps YIPES is less used than YIKES, though that might be regional or generational in nature.

Also, as I'm sure has been pointed out already, the word for "island" in the Sardinian language is "ISULA", not "ISOLA" from Italian. I suppose the clue is correct since Italian is officially spoken there, but I wonder if some Sardinians might object to this clue.

Nits aside, I thought this was a very nice puzzle. Felt a bit Wednesdayish to me, but solved it in a Tusdayish time.
A thoroughly enjoyable puzzle!

It's amusing to me that in a puzzle that's themed on the paucity of VOWELs that we get OUI OUI as an answer.  "Nothing but VOWELs!"
AUSPICIOUS also stands out in this regard.

And TIL about the KARA Sea.  I don't think I'd ever heard of it before, and I needed all the crosses to solve it.
It's nice to get a complete unknown on a Tuesday.

Back in the early 1980's, I was an active participant in my college's Gay Union. At some point, there was a decision to amend the union's charter, and alter the name, to be more inclusive of lesbians--but whom to give priority?  My friend Wendy advocated for the "Gay-Lesbian Union, " or GLU--"Gays and lesbians sticking together." But in the end, the vote was to make it LGU.

Now, it has become a veritable alphanumeric soup of inclusion--looking on-line this morning, I found a reference to the "LGBTQIAPN+ community." 

Similarly, the Pride Flag--although, at its introduction (1978) the Rainbow Flag had eight colors, within a few years, this was reduced to the familiar six-color. Nowadays, the most common seen is the Progress Pride Flag, which includes the chevron, and introduces five--or in some designs six or seven--*additional* colors.

Keep the message simple, folks!

I‚Äôd like to buoy a consonant in the Kara sea.

Fnpzzl.
:)
Thanks for the deliberate Natick. What a "challenge".

When I SAW NBC SPORTS was airing BOSS BATTLE, I thought it was a PR STUNT, but when EDWIN and I PERUSED the LURES, we SMILEd and said SURE we‚Äôre ready for a RAP DUO doing BMX TRICKS.  

But then a SQUALL came up and OUR coverage WENT PFFT as did the GLITTER on our LGBTQ FLAG.   ‚ÄúOH NO,‚Äù I said, but EDWIN said, ‚ÄúNAH, don‚Äôt ARGUE with fate.  My ESP tells me it‚Äôs an AUSPICIOUS sign.  Besides, there‚Äôs bound to be GAPS.‚Äù  ‚ÄúOUI OUI‚Äù I said.

Bored, I got thinking about my wardrobe and how I wear POLO when making BOGEYs, DKNY when PJS won‚Äôt do, FILA when AT BAT, and SUEDE when visiting the POLES, one of which is where we keep our pet ORCA, who we call ISOLA. She NESTS on the KAVA SEA BED.  

One day, she was DROOLing for some OREOS (something about the colors).  ‚ÄúARE you kidding,‚Äù I said, ‚Äúthe Spanish YETIs made ESOS cookie jars EMPTY, the CADS.  Those ONES never BEHAVE!  Would you settle for a ROMA tomato?‚Äù  

EDWIN APED a YETI eating OREOS to tease ISOLA and then said he‚Äôd lend her his DEBIT card to buy TEN OREOS, and SLIPped in ‚Äúmaybe you can even BUY A VOWEL.‚Äù  

YIKES, ISOLA was furious and BLAREd, f-you and the horse you RODIN on.‚Äù  That caused some JOLTS and I said, SO TO bed I will go, which EDWIN thankfully ECHOed, before ISOLA threatened to SECEDE.

VWLS R SPRFLS.
Consonants carry most of the information in written words, and vowels can be so fluid that we had to invent the schwa.

DHubby still twits me about my pronunciation of PIN/PEN...a possible cause of the Civil War?
YIpES! what a clever puzzle.   Many thanks.

Is it just me?  I filled out the entire puzzle quickly but got stuck on one letter (N).  I'd forgotten that I used to use a coloN for emoticons now that they are provided for me on my phone, and I'd never heard the expression "Nothing but Net". The reference to  "swish" didn't help.
Thank you, Geoffrey and Will, for such a cleverly-constructed Tuesday -- I hope we'll see more collaborations from you!

I guess I won the geography prize by knowing the KARA Sea, but I'm not sure how I knew it. Maybe from a Douglas Reeman book about escorting supply convoys to Russia? But I think those convoys were headed for Murmansk, and wouldn't have gone further than the Barents Sea. Anyway, I knew it.

I dropped in ARGUE at 2D, and immediately removed it, because nothing starts with LG, except for Korean appliances. Then I read the across clue. Sneaky, but amusing.
48 down not being DEBUT stopped this being a checkless puzzle for me

Cute!¬† A nicely original idea that's executed very well.¬† I'm wondering if there's a computer program that enables you to find phrases with only one vowel and a given number of letters.¬† If there isn't one, this is a much more impressive job of execution than if there is.

I'm normally not a big fan of puzzles in which figuring out the theme is completely irrelevant to the solving process.¬† But in this case my belated "Aha" when I saw the revealer was strong enough to make me SMILE.¬† And getting in the chewy, vowel-laden Down answer AUSPICIOUS when, for heaven's sake, you're working with consonants¬†is quite a coup.

The puzzle was good; I was sitting for a while, wondering why I wasn't a "You did it!" message, until I realized that I put HOLES instead of POLES. Oops! Great collab puzzle, and creative theme! See ya! :)

I was amused to note that BUYAVOWEL includes the ‚Äúsometimes‚Äù vowels Y and W. Nice. 

:-)
I've only been crosswording for about 5 years, but I think this is my favorite Tuesday puzzle yet. Thanks, Geoffrey and Will.
OREOS, ORCA, ESP, APED... at what point can we just stop with the same words over and over and over?
This was lots of fun. Kudos to Geoffrey Schorkopf and Will Eisenberg üòä
In re the same words being uses over and over, I miss raree, jai alai (one or the other) and cesta. But then I'm old.
Fun that in a puzzle with a theme about a dearth of vowels, there is one six-letter entry (20-A) that is all vowels!

Here is today's word: SEICHE A seiche (pronounced "saysh") is a standing wave, or sloshing back and forth, in an enclosed or partially enclosed body of water like a lake or harbor, often triggered by strong winds or atmospheric pressure changes that push water to one end, causing it to rebound and oscillate. These rhythmic waves can last minutes to hours, causing dramatic water level shifts, exposing lakebeds, and sometimes leading to flooding or damage, as seen recently on Lake Erie. Seiche has appeared only once, on Saturday, January 2nd, 1982 clued as [Oscillation of a lake's surface]. That was an interesting puzzle. Here's the (solved) xwordinfo link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/2/1982&g=29&d=A

Really missed an opportunity here from a Minnesotan perspective. 


Minnesota Twins All-Time Great Kent

Hrbek

Chris Berman of ESPN, is known for making up clever players nicknames, ie Bert "Be home" Blyleven. 

He nicknamed Kent Hrbek, Kent "Can I buy a vowel?" Hrbek.

Five theme entries plus a revealer. I'm impressed.

In my pile of incomplete puzzle grids are many in which I tried to fit too many theme entries. It makes the puzzle so hard to fill, even with the generous use of crosswordese. 

Like I said, I'm impressed.

I'm fascinated by Sam's choice of photo.
Google-lensed it.
"The image features artist and stage designer Richard Berkeley Sutcliffe in a portrait taken by photographer Francis Goodman on August 10, 1951. 
Sutcliffe was a British artist known for his costume and set designs for theatre and opera.
He worked on productions such as My Fair Lady and The Way of the World."
It's a photo and a painting, and it has a surreal Magritte feel.

There is a story by Asimov in his Black Widowers series in which one of the characters says that what we think of as a foreign accent is largely a deformation of the vowels. Aside:  You wouldn't believe how much trouble I went through to get "afficionados" above spelled correctly.   The reason is the red-line underline guy thinks it only has one "f".  That's a secondary spelling, according to MW.

D≈ºd≈ºysty - one of the weirdest Polish words, meaning "characterized by persistent light rain" - contains no vowels by English standards, doesn't it? 

Also, "chrzƒÖszcz" (beetle), has just one vowel, and surely looks totally loco to non-Polish speakers ü§™

@Francis

Strength has appeared 5 times in the modern era, 6 times in pre-Shortz days, and once in a variety puzzle.

Strengths appeared only once in the modern era clued as [Longest word in English containing only one vowel] and once in the pre-Shortz era clued as 
[Degrees of intensity].

@Francis

There's that, yes. Also, consider "eighths" and "strengths" - have you any idea how c¬Æ@zy those words look to me? And the pronunciation... Ye gods!

@Andrzej
Y can be the vowel!  (There are no actual words w/out at least one vowel, and there are two common words consistiing of a single vowel.)

BY, SKY  (long Y--sounds like long i)
Baby (short y--sounds like long e)
Plural BABY--"Change the Y to i and add -ES"

@Francis
A rare moment. I'm siding with the machine. One F in aficionado. I think the MW is wrong. Perhaps this is a Btitish vs. USian divergence?

@Jimin

That's a strange one that caused me a bit of concern.   On some ballot forms one places an "X" in a box to vote for the person who is linked to that box.

So, changing the X to a verb, we now have people Xed a box.  Common rules of English allow for prepositions to follow a verb form and "in" was a natural preposition because the voter made the X in the box.

Hence, we get XEDIN or Xed In.

@Jimin
If you fill out a ballot by hand, you may mark your selection with an x thus XES IN.

@Francis

It's more than made up for by your impressive explanation of the entry. ;-)

@Francis
Good explanation but I suspect that JiMin's dictionaries failed because the act of placing an X is more commonly spelled exes, exed, exing. The shorter version without an initial E is the dreaded VAR(iant).  Good enough for crosswords but maybe not enough for some dictionaries.

@Andrzej
Forgive my ignorance but it appears that Polish has many more letters or variants than English. When a Polish WoF player looks at the unused  letter board, how many letters are they choosing from? How many vowels? If they call, say, an L, do they get all the varieties of L? ≈Å? ƒª? etc.

@SBK

Our special letters are ƒô, √≥, ≈õ, ≈Ç, ≈º, ≈∫, and ƒá. We don't consider a ≈Å a variant of L - the sound is completely different. Our L is a simple ell sound, while ≈Å is the W sound of "wonder". @Andrzej
Yes, our vowels do double-duty.  
SHORT vowels (A as in ACT, E as in EDGE, i as in IF, O as in OCTOPUS, U as in US) are often taught first...
and for the LONG sound (the vowel's name)--there is usually a signal or spelling arrangement to make the Short vowel Long:  Final silent E--CON becomes CONE.  Or two vowels together:  "when two vowels go awalkin' the first one does the talkin' "....TWEAK!...  that's the simplified introduction...  English language spelling is complicated, but 80% is phonetically regular, so it can be mastered...

@Vaer I just went down a W as a vowel rabbit hole. English is pretty ridiculous sometimes.

@CrispyShot, I always heard about W sometimes being a vowel, too, while growing up and never understood why. That is, until browsing through my Random House Collegiate dictionary one night (I use to do that as a teen) and coming across this word: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/crwth Not a word ending sound, not a vowel combination sound, just an honest-to-gosh VOWEL in the middle of a word. @CrispyShot
I absolutely agree! In fact, in the very word VOWEL I would argue that the W is acting pretty much as a U. In Italian to transliterate the English word "wow" we write "uau". Not to mention, of course, the Welsh vowel W. In sum, as far as I can see, W is every bit as much a vowel as Y (sometimes or not).

@Susan E while I love the nuanced, informed responses that followed, my original comment was entirely based on the mnemonic I learned as a child, more than 50 years ago: ‚ÄúA, E, I, O, U, and sometimes Y and W‚Äù.

@CrispyShot

I never heard that W is a vowel. However, one important lesson from my class in The History of the English Language is this:
In 1066, William the Conqueror conquered England. French became the official language for 200 years. People in the king's court spoke French. The common people continued to speak but were not allowed to write the English language. Over two hundred years, a language changes. Normally, these changes would show up in the written language. However, in this case, since writing English was prohibited, the written language remained archaic, a dodo, let's say. With the old spellings.

When English became spoken again, you had a new language with an out-of-date writing system. Voil√†! All the dumb spellings in English.

@Name2 

Part of what makes the NYT Crossword the NYT Crossword is the repeated use of signature clues, especially OREO.

The other examples listed are often used in construction because they are short and contain As and Es, which typically facilitate cross-answers better than the other vowels.

If you want some variety, branch out and play puzzles from other publications ‚Äî but don't be surprised when you see some overlap.

@Name2

I doubt there are many constructors who *like* using ep√™e, Oreo, aped, etc. Most of those words are vowel-heavy and simply work well in a crossword grid.

"...at what point can we just stop with the same words over and over and over?"

At the same point that we no longer use some words more than others in our everyday speech and writing.
